comments:
I've been trying to define a map feature in an interface whose getter and setter are not in the interface (getSuppressedVisibility="true").  I've defined it this way:

/**
* @model
*    features="properties"
*       propertiesKeyType="java.lang.String"
*       propertiesValueType="xxx.Element"
*       propertiesSuppressedGetVisibility="true"
*/
public interface Propertied {
....
}

When I run this through the EMF generator, I get an NPE with the attached stack trace.  If I rename the feature to _properties, it will run without generating an exception, but the generated interface will have a method get_properties() in it (i.e., visibility is not suppressed).  The above works if I specify keyType="java.lang.String" and valueType="java.lang.Object".

Created an attachment (id=47158)
Patch to fix the problem

The problem is that for EReferences, the resolved key or value type must be an EClass and the resolve method has a guard to ensure it doesn't return an EDataType when resolving for an EReference.  But in this case, the EReference is for an EMap and we need to be able to resolve to new EDataTypes for the key and value types.  So I used the trick of passing in the container of the EReference, i.e., the EClass, and to resolve in that context instead.
The fix has been committed to CVS.
